data.title: Student Profiles
data.text:
Sophie Ack

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Wellesley College - Neuroscience

Mentor: Rodrigo Braga and Lisa Johnson

Research Project Description:

I am broadly interested in exploring cognitive neuroscience, including understanding the neural systems underlying complex decision-making, memory, and cognitive control at the human level. I am also interested in combining methods, insights, and questions from multiple disciplines from social science to computer science in order to better understand the relationship between the brain and mind.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN because it combines large university resources with a true community experience, and emphasizes an interdisciplinary approach. I was impressed with the closeness of the cohorts and the glowing reviews of faculty mentors across the board, and knew there would be resources and support available for every need.

Lyn Ackert-Smith

PhD program entry year: 2022

Undergraduate: Middlebury College - Neuroscience

Mentor: Lucas Pinto

Research Project Description:

My research interests are in understanding the computations and population dynamics underlying motor control and the integration of sensory information in sensorimotor systems, as well as in leveraging this understanding to decode brain activity and predict behaviors.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN because of the multitude of faculty, engaged students, and wide range of research opportunities. The sense of community within the program also really spoke to me.

Ayomiposi Adewakun

PhD program entry year: 2024

Undergraduate: New York University

Research Project Description:

I'm interested broadly in the neurophysiology driving behavior. To a more specific extent, I'm interested in studying the circuit and cellular mechanisms involved in different behaviors and paradigms (learning & memory, social behavior, decision making, psychiatric disorders).

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN for my PhD because the program's connection across both the Evanston and Chicago campuses provides flexibility in faculty, projects, resources, and perspectives. I believe that this structure gives more opportunities to PhD trainees, both as a student and as a professional.

Amira Affaneh

PhD program entry year: 2017

Undergraduate: DePaul University - Neuroscience

Mentor: Jack Kessler

Research Project Description:

My thesis project focuses on the effects of APOE on transsynaptic spread of phosphorylated tau in Alzheimer's disease (AD). I use an induced pluripotent stem cell model, in which I differentiate stem cells from AD patients into neurons and study the effects of APOE in a neuronal culture independently of glia.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN not only for the high-caliber neuroscience being conducted at Northwestern University, but for NUIN's sense of community. NUIN has a very collaborative environment where students truly care about each others well-being and it shows the minute you are recruited to defending your thesis and that is one of the most valuable aspects of our program.

Jacqueline Allen

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Cornell University - Psychology, Philosophy, and Government

Mentor: Jack Kessler

Research Project Description:

I am broadly interested in studying the biological mechanisms underlying pathological and healthy aging, with the ultimate aim of identifying potential strategies for treating neurodegenerative diseases. My primary interests lie in cellular and molecular neurobiology, but I'm also curious about how biological, psychological, and social factors combine to shape individual differences in aging outcomes.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN for the diversity of ongoing research, the collaborative community, and the multitude of opportunities and resources available. One of my favorite aspects of neuroscience is its interdisciplinary nature, and as an interdepartmental program, NUIN is the perfect setting for me to explore my interests and grow as a neuroscientist.

Petros Basakis

PhD program entry year: 2024

Undergraduate: Davidson College

Research Project Description:

My previous research interests revolve around neurodevelopment, neuroendocrinology, neurodegeneration, and aging. By integrating these interdisciplinary fields, I aim to unravel the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying age-related neurodegeneration in the central nervous system and develop regenerative strategies for systemic anti-aging.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

NUIN's interdisciplinary focus can strengthen my understanding of neurodegeneration as a system of targets for neuroregeneration. I really appreciate the opportunity to experience both Chicago- and Evanston-based research. Having co-curricular access to NIH-funded training programs (i.e., MAD and GMCMD) particularly through CNADC, I am confident that NUIN can equip me with intra- and interdisciplinary training in the multidisciplinary field of age-related disease.

Jasmine Benitez

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Emmanuel College; Northwestern Univeristy - BS in Neuroscience; MS in Neurobiology

Mentor: Fred Turek and Martha Vitaterna

Research Project Description:

I am interested in understanding the genetics of the circadian clock system and the molecular genetic mechanisms underlying the sleep-wake cycle and the role of disrupted circadian rhythms on neurodegenerative disease. For my MS degree, I developed a thesis project that focused on characterizing the time course of sleep-wake abnormalities and behavioral/cognitive changes in the MC1-Park mouse model of Parkinson's Disease and I am interested in expanding this research.

Daniel Bennett

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Cornell University - Biological Sciences, concentration in Neurobiology and Behavior

Mentor: Marco Gallio

Research Project Description:

I am currently investigating the mechanisms underlying species-specific humidity preferences, with a particular focus on those of the desert fruit fly Drosophila mojavensis. By identifying and comparing the humidity-linked neuronal differences between Drosophilids occupying contrasting environmental conditions, I hope to shed light on how humidity preference evolved over time in Drosophila.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I started off as a lab technician in the Gallio lab but in no time realized that I not only thoroughly enjoyed the research I was conducting, but also had a natural connection with the lab I was in. The VINE Scholars Program offered me an opportunity to seamlessly transition into my graduate studies while also continuing my project in the Gallio Lab. This was an offer I just couldn't refuse.

Eleni Bougioukli

PhD program entry year: 2024

Undergraduate: Brandeis University

Research Project Description:

Although I am keeping an open mind and I am ready to explore as much as possible during my first year, my main interests lie in rehabilitation research. I am specifically interested in helping stroke patients improve their quality of life.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

On top of the plethora of interesting labs, I found Northwestern's community very welcoming. All the students I interacted with so far have been more than helpful with their advice, as well as genuinely happy with their life and research at NUIN.

Emily Breach

PhD program entry year: 2024

Undergraduate: The University of Texas at Austin

Research Project Description:

I'm interested in investigating the interaction between the nervous, endocrine, and immune system during chronic stress. I’m particularly interested in researching autoimmunity, stress disorders, chronic pain, or neurodegeneration. I want to better understand how genetics play a role in disease pathogenesis and use translational medicine to develop better treatments. I’m drawn to molecular biology, structural biology, and electrophysiological approaches.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

Northwestern has great translation medicine research opportunities because of NUIN's proximity and connection to the medical campus. Additionally, the administrative staff seem very kind and supportive of students which is very important to me. I also think the research going on at Northwestern is super fascinating and I love the city of Chicago!

Chris Cyr

PhD program entry year: 2020

Undergraduate: University of Michigan - Neuroscience, Physics Minor

Mentor: Rodrigo Braga

Research Project Description:

My work investigates the electrophysiological correlates of large scale networks as defined by resting state fMRI.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN for the community. While interviewing, I was surrounded by a welcoming community of scientists that were truly connected to one another, that shared more than just interests in neuroscience. I knew that it was a community that could support me through graduate school. I also chose Northwestern for the city of Chicago, and the opportunity to investigate invasive electrophysiological studies in humans.

Emily Dexter

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Case Western Reserve University - Biology

Mentor: Jeffrey Savas

Research Project Description:

I am interested in studying the pathology of neurodegenerative diseases, with a particular interest in Alzheimer's Disease and other forms of dementia, to identify and develop therapeutic treatments.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN for my PhD studies because I felt that it offered a multitude of opportunities to explore my interests in neurodegenerative diseases and the program is designed to support the students in various aspects. The NUIN community is enthusiastic to learn and grow in the field of Neuroscience.

Brian Druciak

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Johns Hopkins University - Neuroscience

Mentor: David Gate

Research Project Description:

The Apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene encodes for a protein, ApoE, that is involved in lipid transport in mammals and is strongly associated with the risk of developing late-stage Alzheimer’s disease (AD). This project will explore the role of different APOE variants in regulating lipid metabolism and studying how this impacts the adaptive immune response. This study will utilize novel genomic, lipidomic, and immunohistochemical approaches to evaluate ApoE-mediated modulation of adaptive immunity in neurodegenerative diseases.

Melissa Fajardo

PhD program entry year: 2019

Undergraduate: Florida International University - Biological Sciences; Psychology

Mentor: CJ Heckman

Research Project Description:

My projects mainly focus on neuromodulatory effects in motor control and how it changes across muscles, with age, as well as under neurological and motor disease. While I currently work with human subjects, I am also interested in developing a reliable and accurate motoneuron models through computer stimulations to further explore mechanisms behind motor control.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

As I was looking for PhD programs that would allow me to focus on research related to motor control, I found that the NUIN program would be the best fit for me. I especially like the interdepartmental aspect of the program because it affords me opportunities to work with experts adjacent to the research area I'm interested in.

Donte Garcia

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Purdue University - Behavioral Neuroscience

Mentor: Jack Kessler

Research Project Description:

My research interests lie in studying the pathobiology of neurodegenerative diseases and dementias. Many neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s Disease have no full pathological understanding which has led to a lack of effective treatments, recognition/preventative mechanisms, and no cures. Studying how cellular and molecular mechanisms contribute to disease development and dementia behavior fascinates me. My goal with my research is to contribute to pathological understanding, treatment, and prevention of neurodegenerative diseases and dementias.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN for my PhD studies because of its interdepartmental emphasis. My interest being in neuroscience, it was important to me to have interdepartmental resources and collaboration to bolster my research and understanding of the nervous system on different levels. This alongside personalized mentorship would provide me with the environment I needed to carry out encompassing and translational research from the molecular/cellular level to the human behavioral level.

Ania Holubecki

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Northwestern University - Neuroscience (Human Behavior and Cognition), Spanish Minor

Mentor: Rodrigo Braga

Research Project Description:

My prior research experiences include characterizing the neural correlates of autism spectrum disorder, as well as characterizing large-scale brain networks at the level of an individual. During my graduate training, I am interested in utilizing neuroimaging and human electrophysiology to study social cognition. This includes exploring how heterogeneity (both in behavior and in brain anatomy) can help us understand brain function in social cognition, as well as how this changes through development into adulthood.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

Having spent seven years collaborating with members of the NUIN community as both an undergraduate and a research coordinator, I experienced firsthand the exceptional training the program offers. I wanted to continue engaging with NUIN's interdisciplinary community during my graduate training, including with experts in my research interests. I also really appreciate the resources Northwestern has to support students. Lastly, I know I will have strong support system outside of the lab in Chicago!

Achint Kaur

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign - Molecular and Cellular Biology and Behavioral Neuroscience

Mentor: Robert Vassar

Research Project Description:

I am fascinated by exploring aging and neurodegeneration through the perspective of brain resilience. Instead of delving into why most individuals experience cognitive decline as they age, I am intrigued by the minority who maintain cognitive abilities into old age. By studying this subgroup of aging individuals, we may uncover valuable insights into factors that contribute to their "anti-aging" effects. This knowledge could eventually pave the way for therapeutic interventions in the future.

Lisa Kim

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Barnard College - Neuroscience & Behavior

Mentor: Raj Awatramani

Research Project Description:

I am interested in the machinery of neural circuits and how they control behavior. I am particularly interested in the molecular and cellular bases of the basal ganglia network during development, as this is likely fundamental to the long-distance connectivity that forms the basis of circuit function and various neuropsychiatric disorders, if disrupted.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN because of its highly supportive research community and inclusive educational environment. I felt a genuine culture of collaborative support that was tangible even through virtual interviewing. I’m also excited to be part of a program with such a strong commitment to promoting diversity in academia.

Fangze Li

PhD program entry year: 2021

Undergraduate: Macalester College - Neuroscience Studies

Mentor: Jack Kessler

Research Project Description:

I am interested in studying the sensory systems, in particular the olfactory system. I would like to explore the connections between perception, sensation, behavior, and how they influence each other, on a systematic, cellular, and molecular level.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I believe that NUIN will present me with ample opportunities in neuroscience research and career development. On top of that, I love Chicago!

Yun-Pu Li

PhD program entry year: 2022

Undergraduate: National Taiwan University - Life Science

Mentor: John Kessler

Research Project Description:

My previous research focused on how lights affect the oscillation of gut microbiota and how dysbiosis leads to the progression of Parkinson's disease in mice. I am interested in the field of neurological disorders, particularly neurodegenerative diseases. I am looking forward to working more on the molecular basis of Parkinson's disease and hope to find a solution to stop this disease.

Yasmeen Lowe

PhD program entry year: 2022

Undergraduate: DePaul University - Neuroscience

Mentor: Shana Augustin

Research Project Description:

I am interested in exploring neural circuits and behavior. Specifically how different factors (i.e. stress) influence the development of neural circuits and how it alters behavior in adulthood.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN because I felt like the faculty really cared about mentoring and student success, regardless of whether you were in their lab or not. This paired with NUIN's interdisciplinary approach to neuroscience would enable me to conduct research across different aspects of biology/neuroscience while feeling supported of my career and individual goals.

Laura Magaña-Hernandez

PhD program entry year: 2022

Undergraduate: University of California, Santa Cruz - MS in Cell & Molecular Biology

Mentor: Alicia Guemez-Gamboa

Research Project Description:

My research focuses on investigating changes in molecular and cellular pathways that contribute to neurodevelopmental disorders. I use induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) from patients to generate organoids predisposed to neurodevelopmental disorders. These disorders are characterized by microcephaly, white matter abnormalities, intellectual disability and epilepsy.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN because of the opportunities I saw to collaborate with faculty from other departments. I also found the NUIN community to be close knit and this made me feel more welcomed.

Sebastian Malagon Perez

PhD program entry year: 2021

Undergraduate: Pontificia University Javeriana - Electronics Engineering

Mentor: Ann Kennedy

Research Project Description:

I am interested in the processes that arise from the interaction between an animal and the environment, particularly how motor actions are intertwined with cognitive functions and the intentions of the animal. By combining experimental, computational, and theoretical neuroscience, I would like to dissect behavioral and neural mechanisms underlying flexible and context-dependent control of movement. I am highly interested in the manipulation of the sensorimotor loop using brain-computer interfaces.

Joseph Mastroni

PhD program entry year: 2021

Undergraduate: University of Notre Dame - Neuroscience & Behavior

Mentor: Joe Bass

Research Project Description:

I am broadly interested in investigating biological rhythms at all levels of neuroscience - from the cellular and molecular to the behavioral. Specifically, I am interested in investigating the intersection of biological rhythms and neurological disorders in humans. I hope to conduct research on both the sleep/wake cycle and circadian rhythms so as to understand how a disruption in one of those biological rhythms can relate to neurological disorders.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN for my PhD because of the collaborative and supportive atmosphere that surrounds the research done in the program. The size of the program, as well as the option to research both in Evanston and in downtown Chicago, naturally breeds interdisciplinary study and collaboration, which I really value in my research goals.

Joe Minton

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: University of Massachusetts Amherst; University of Michigan - BS in Psychology; MS in Pharmacology

Mentor: Gemma Carvill

Research Project Description:

I am interested in the genetic and molecular mechanisms underlying neurodevelopment and neurodevelopmental disorders. Understanding the genetic and molecular mechanisms of development can provide insight into novel biomarkers and therapeutic targets needed to identify and treat pathological development. I hope to expand my knowledge of cellular and molecular neuroscience, as well as pharmacological applications.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN for the community and the broad range of research. NUIN fosters a collaborative community of students, faculty, staff, and departments that leads to innovative and renowned research. This paired with the supportive community that values the graduate experience made it the right pick for me.

Matthew Neehouse

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Ohio University; Ohio State University - BS in Biological Sciences; DPT in Physical Therapy

Mentor: Martin Oudega and Monica Perez

Research Project Description:

I am most interested in spinal cord injury rehabilitation and recovery. With my clinical background in physical therapy, I hope to fill the gaps that exist for patients effected by neurological injuries such as SCI. My hopes are to gain a better understanding of the mechanisms and pathology that underlie injury through translational research so that patients may achieve an improved quality of life and remove some of the burden created by injury.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

NUIN provided the most complete program as far as researchers, faculty, facilities, and overall resources. This program also provides access to some of the best hospitals and research facilities in the country which will allow me to pursue my goals of becoming a successful translational researcher.

Annie Nguyen

PhD program entry year: 2024

Undergraduate: Johns Hopkins University

Research Project Description:

My interest is in studying the structure and function of the retina, as well as the neural circuit that comprises the visual system. In addition, I'm also interested in studying the effects of disruptions (such as diseases and disorders) on the system and finding ways to mitigate those disruptions.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

Throughout the interview process and later the visit to Northwestern, I always felt very welcomed by the faculty. Everyone that I've talked to are friendly, enthusiastic, and helpful in answering any questions that I had. Overall, it creates an environment where I want to be in for the next few years. That, and the interesting research projects that are going on in NUIN, helped me chose NUIN.

Leonardo Pinzón Avendaño

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Universidad Nacional de Colombia - Biology

Mentor: Murali Prakriya

Research Project Description:

I am interested in how the sensory systems capture the information of the outside environment and the way this is transmitted and processed in ulterior structures to build an internal representation of the world. I would like to address this question by studying the dynamics of ion channels and neuronal circuits, as well as investigating how alterations or modulations at these levels can impact behavior.

Zuoheng Qin

PhD program entry year: 2021

Undergraduate: University of Melbourne - Neuroscience

Mentor: Congcong He

Research Project Description:

The mechanisms underlying and the therapies of neurodegenerative diseases are always my interest. In the past few years, I have investigated the roles of the neuronally-expressed p75 neurotrophin receptor, as a potential drug target of Guillain-Barré syndrome, in PNS neuronal development and myelination processes. Also did some screening works looking for the Clk-controlled genes which ameliorate symptoms of Huntington's diseases. I will keep staying in this research area during my PhD time.

Isabelle Rieth

PhD program entry year: 2021

Undergraduate: Carleton College - Psychology; Neuroscience

Mentor: Genia Kozorovitskiy

Research Project Description:

I am interested in neuroendocrinology, sex differences and social behaviors. Additionally, I would like to explore how short-term and prolonged stress impacts the brain and body.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN not only because it was a reputable program with many great mentors to choose from, but also because I could sense how happy the graduate students were with their experience doing research at Northwestern.

Virginia Rodriguez

PhD program entry year: 2022

Undergraduate: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign - Behavioral neuroscience

Mentor: Luis Rosas-Vidal

Research Project Description:

I am interested in the circuit mechanisms of maladaptive behaviors such as addiction and the overlaps that these networks have with anxiety and depressive disorders.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

Having worked in the Pinto lab before applying, I really fell in love with the collaborative environment that NU offers. There’s so much great science happening at this institution with even great faculty, post-docs, staff, and students. I’m so excited to part of such a healthy environment.

Yeonju Sin

PhD program entry year: 2023

Undergraduate: Ulsan National Institute of Science and Technology (UNIST) - Biological Sciences and Human Factors Engineering

Mentor: Sachin Patel

Research Project Description:

I am interested in the neural mechanisms of maladaptive behavioral responses to stress and how stress affects neural circuits that mediate psychiatric disorders such as anxiety and depression. I am also interested in research on stress resilience like its individual or sex differences.

Ziyad Sultan

PhD program entry year: 2021

Undergraduate: University of Wisconsin - Madison - B.S. Neurobiology

Mentor: Indira Raman

Research Project Description:

I am studying the unique biophysical characteristics of inferior olivary neurons (e.g., long-lasting action potential afterdepolarizations, gap junctional coupling, subthreshold oscillations) and their contribution to olivocerebellar function.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

NUIN has an enormous faculty list, which allowed me the flexibility to explore my interests in neuroscience through the first year rotations before deciding on a thesis laboratory. In addition, I felt very welcomed during my interviews by NUIN faculty, staff, and students, and I could not turn down an opportunity to live in the city of Chicago!

Linqing Sun

PhD program entry year: 2021

Undergraduate: Carnegie Mellon University - Neuroscience

Mentor: Jim Surmeier

Research Project Description:

My research interest focuses on the cellular and molecular pathophysiologies during mammalian brain aging and neurodegeneration. I'm interested in studying genetic and epigenetic mechanisms preceding or during disease pathogenesis. Additionally, I'm also curious about internal or external factors that promote or delay the neuropathology, such as interactions between the brain and different organ systems, medications, and other environmental exposures. To this end, I look forward to working with disease models and exploring human studies.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

During my school search, I found that NUIN has a large multidisciplinary scientific community and offers strong translational research training with many faculty research in line with my research interest. Through the interview weekends, I could also feel that NUIN is a very welcoming community with academic and cultural diversity and provides individualized training. I believe I would best benefit from such an environment to find support while exploring my research and career focuses.

Estella Tcaturian

PhD program entry year: 2022

Undergraduate: Lake Forest College - Neuroscience, Chemistry

Mentor: Navdeep Chandel

Research Project Description:

I am particularly interested in studying neuronal metabolism and its involvement in different neurological pathologies. I hope to potentially contribute to the field by discovering new drug targets for the diseases, as well as help design effective and potent treatments for them. I am excited to additionally work on learning and improving and developing new techniques for studying neuronal metabolism given how understudied the field is.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN for so many reasons, one of them is that NUIN is an interdepartmental program, and given my strong interests not only in neuroscience but in chemistry and pharmacology, this program will actually allow me to both take courses and choose a lab and a project that fit my interests in both Neuroscience and Pharmacology perfectly.

Le Trung Tran

PhD program entry year: 2022

Undergraduate: University of Medicine and Pharmacy at Hochiminh City - Medical Lab Science

Mentor: Greg Schwartz

Research Project Description:

My interests are diversed, from the structure and function of different channels to the connectomics of the brain. I also hope to be able to develop novel techniques to contribute to the research of this field.

Andrew Ulmer

PhD program entry year: 2022

Undergraduate: Purdue University - Computer Engineering

Mentor: Ann Kennedy and Joshua Glaser

Research Project Description:

I am broadly interested in developing and applying interpretable machine learning methods to understanding the neural mechanisms and observed behavior of interacting animals. In the past I focused on unsupervised techniques that identify common behavioral motifs. In the future, I would like to explore if and how animals anticipate the actions of one another.

Xavier Valencia

PhD program entry year: 2024

Undergraduate: University of Chicago

Research Project Description:

Neurodevelopmental disorders, learning, E/I imbalance, and neuroprosthetics

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN for its reputation for fostering students’ science skills inside and outside of the lab. I am also eager to explore the untapped research areas yet to be developed through NUIN’s interdisciplinary and collaborative community

Xunhui Wu

PhD program entry year: 2021

Undergraduate: University of Toronto - Genetics

Mentor: Jones Parker

Research Project Description:

My research interests are neurodevelopmental and neurodegeneration diseases. I wish to study their molecular mechanisms and develop potential therapeutics. Specifically, the development of animal and cellular models, and analyses of proteomics and transcriptomics.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

NUIN hosts a huge variety of labs focusing on different aspects of neuroscience. It allows students to choose what they're most interested in.

Qiaohan Yang

PhD program entry year: 2021

Undergraduate: Northwestern University - Neurobiology

Mentor: Christina Zelano

Research Project Description:

My research experience so far has been focusing on using intracranial EEG to examine the cortical response to odor in the human olfactory system. Generally, I'm interested in computational neuroscience and would like to explore more techniques and methods to study the population-level dynamics of sensory information encoding in both human and other model organisms.

Josset Yarbrough

PhD program entry year: 2022

Undergraduate: University of California, Santa Cruz - Neuroscience

Mentor: Lisa Johnson

Research Project Description:

I am broadly interested in auditory processing and its behavioral and functional relationship to the temporal limbic system (memory and mood).

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

I chose NUIN for my PhD studies because of the diverse research opportunities in synaptic physiology and learning and memory. I also really enjoy Chicago.

Jinglan Zhang

PhD program entry year: 2022

Undergraduate: Capital Medical University - Basic Medical Sciences

Mentor: Yevgenia Kozorovitskiy

Research Project Description:

I'm delving into the role of purinergic receptors in the ventral striatum, concurrently, I'm collaborating with the renowned Dr. John Rogers's lab to advance innovations in the realm of brain-machine interfaces. These parallel pursuits merge the intricacies of neurobiology with cutting-edge technological advancements, presenting an exciting intersection of science and innovation.

Why did I choose NUIN for my studies?

Faculty match is always my first priority in choosing the program, and NUIN is the perfect place for me! With over a hundred outstanding faculties working here, I can choose to work with scientists whose interests match perfectly with mine, or try to explore in a new area that I'm not familiar with. In a word, I choose NUIN to embrace infinite possibilities.
